No doubt for very sound reasons, the heated bed on my Prusa i3 is supported on three not-very-well-separated linear bearings. This set-up has a harmonic frequency that gets triggered at various points as the bed is moved in the Y-axis. The result is an intermittent buzz/hum that is expressed in the object being printed.  
A pair of these 'things' are clipped onto the rear on my bed and rest on the Y-axis rails (notched side to rail). The result is a significant reduction in the buzz/hum, and thus an improvement in the quality of my prints.  
Note that installing a pair of these 'things' could impact the full range of your Y-axis.

comments.text:
Did you use cable ties/zip ties to hold the 3 LM8UU bearings to the Y frame? If so this is part of your problem as the original person who thought up such a scheme should be tarred and feathered then sliced to slowly bleed out. Really, cable ties are not mean't to hold anything in only to hold a bunch of wires together. Something that IMMENSELY helps with all sorts of Y issues can be found using something like this (I mean why not the Y frame already is tapped for M3 screws): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:278941http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
So, instead of this really flimsy, and thin, piece of plastic holding only 1 part of the bearing (basically like trying to hold King Kong with one strand of dental floss) these types of dealios screw into the plate and hold the entire bearing. You do give up a little Z but for an I3 the amount you give up is nothing at all for the overwhelming advantages these sorts of things give.

description.text:
First off, this is a MAJOR work in progress. In theory, all parts in this file should be cable of printing, but I am not planning to test them all! If you want to test them, feel free! I can say that the solid model will work! User InfiniTTTy printed it and it came out great! There is some info I need to express about the pack models though:
  • ALL of these are in a 1:25.4 scale exactly. You will need to upscale to make them 1:1, and slice them as well (netfabb is your friend!).
  • A few of these parts are off by a smige. Some of the parts had sloped edges I had a heck of time getting in the models, so they are not there.
  • The bar is no where near accurate. Its close, but not accurate.
    • Second, credit due! These models were made using Stefan Otto and Norms pack plans. I used Stefans for 90% of this, and norms for the rest. If you plan to make a proton pack, I HIGHY advise you check these guys plans out! Both can be found at the GhostBuster fan page
    Link: www.gbfans.com/equipment/plans/ Finally: I do plan to make my own pack, however, I do not plan to 3D print the entire thing! I only plan to print some of the more complex parts (such as the booster frame, clippard valves, etc) These were all created in AutoCAD 2012 (and yes, I know, there are much better 3D modeling programs. But CAD is what I learned and what I am most comfortable using). I do not plan to release the main files at this time, because my digital work space is a total mess (picture attached for this). I will also stick some handy links in the instructions tab for those wanting to make their own packs. In the meantime, get as much use from these files as you can!
    More links!!
    My wand
    My collection of Ghostbuster Gear

As promised, links! First off, GBFans are a GREAT bunch! check out their site here:
http://www.gbfans.com/ Second, Jack Doud has a site for making props, and has an awesome setup for the lights on the pack! This doesn't have sound, but I plan to make my own rig for that, that I will share once done. His site: http://www.bloody-plastic.com/costumes.html This site is also great! This project as all the parts for the pack itself, but there are members here that have done better jobs of certain parts. Lough has a fantastic clippard and bumper bar that puts mine to shame. His profile: http://www.thingiverse.com/loughkb/designs And finally, Instructables. Most of you may have this site bookmarked, but for those who do not have it set: this is another fantastic site. You may need to use them more for electronics and tools (hotwire, for example) but there are a few great packs on there too!. Link to the site: http://www.instructables.com/

description.text: A (very) old vacuum cleaner had a broken attachment that joins the main unit to the hose. Measured and designed the profile of the part in sketchup, did a 'Follow Me' to make it a cylinder, then exported to STL, printed on a Replicator and voila... problem solved. PS: This video helped with using the Follow Me tool in Sketchup: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OL7jvE9So6c

When using ReplicatorG with the .STL file downloaded from this page, I'd suggest ensuring the model has the hose attachment on the platform, and the end that locks into the cleaner is at the top. I printed with 50% fill (for it to be strong) and with full support & a raft. Some external diameters are larger than the original part (where it made no difference to function), also for added strength. On finish, remove support material and check the part in the 'socket' of the vacuum cleaner. If it doesn't turn and lock, sand slightly behind locking tabs as well as the main face that meets the cleaner until it does. Suggest using soap and water to assist refitting hose over barb tail on other end of the part. Suggest improvements:
  • The protruding hose barb fitting could meet the main cylinder in a smooth chamfer - would add strength and make fitting the hose a bit easier.
  • 4 x supporting ribs on the remaining exposed section (when assembled) would help the part resist breakage given the hose will apply fairly strong and regular lateral forces when in use.
    • PS: My second designed and printed object using Makerbot Replicator.

description.text:
Makerbot Replicator spool bracket for even smaller diameter spools (28mm), with larger width (up to 95mm). Genealogy:
/thing:23510 - shaft design
/thing:23773 - joinery This bracket suits 1kg and 1.25kg filament spools supplied by BilbyCNC, Australia. Also attached the Sketchup design for those who prefer it. Otherwise import into your favourite design tool, in millimetres.

The STL file download on the left of this page is ready to print - no glue or assembly required. For my environment, the sequence I use is:
  • Start "Pre-heat" on the Replicator (HBP only)
  • Launch ReplicatorG and open the STL downloaded from Thingiverse
  • Move/Rotate the model as you wish, just ensure it's "on the platform"
  • Generate .gCode file:
    -- Raft/support: yes (works well for me)
    -- Fill: 50 (strong, to handle 1.5kg+ spools)
    -- Temps: HBP 115'C and Extruder 223'C works for me.
    -- (everything else at default)
  • Generate .s3g onto SD card - with short filename.
  • (move SD card to Replicator)
  • (on Replicator) "Print from SD card", select the file and you're sorted.

A set of 4 constraints for the Replicator's HBP washers. It can be a real chore to keep them all aligned when removing and replacing the HBP and this will ensure that all of the washers are aligned during assembly and will not shift during operation. There is ~1mm of tolerance with the washers on my Replicator and a few millimeters of clearance when the springs are fully compressed. NOTE It seems that newer replicators are shipping without these washers under the springs making this system unnecessary. Awesome!

Print off the constraints and remove the HBP from the carriage.
Place the constraints over the washers and re-assemble the HBP. The washers will remain aligned making the process much easier!

comments.text: Thanks ="thingiverse-af34be57099ff6edbabb1a93a45b858f:disqus" href="http://disqus.com/thingiverse-af34be57099ff6edbabb1a93a45b858f/swihart for the hints, I didn't seem to need to repair the stl file. Repetier printed it perfectly this time. I found that the Printrbot Metal Simple must have the extruder cooled in order to keep it from clogging - period. This is a problem. The motor heats up but it isn't the source of the heat, but the hot end conducting heat into the aluminum extruder. What was happening to me is that the extruder was heating up and partially melting the PLA as it comes into the extruder and it softens can't feed so winds up jamming then clogging. I need a fan out front. I have been using a blow dryer with no heat to cool the extruder. With this spool tender and the fan, this is a perfect printer! Thanks to mayermi for the design! It is very strong and I think will work well! Picture when my bearings arrive. Thanks
comments.author: kdpainter

comments.text: When I first loaded it into Repetier, I got a warning about it not being manifold, so I "repaired" the stl file at http://netfabb.orgnetfabb.org. Then it was still "outside the print area" but the object itself fits within the 150 mm by 150 mm print area of the Printrbot Simple Metal. I just changed the setting in Slic3r under Configure: Print Settings: Skirt and brim to put the skirt 1 mm from the object (the default may have been 6 mm). Then it fit and printed on the 1st try. Good Luck.

This is a birthday gift for my girlfriend - personalized nightlight lamp. I made it in one day.
My main inspiration source was these beautiful lamps: http://www.hannahnunn.co.uk/products/table-lamps.html. But since I couldn't order them, I tried to create smth by myself.
Thanks to this pic http://www.123rf.com/photo_21258485_seamless-pattern-with-donuts-and-cookies.html for the donut pattern.

Materials and Intruments:
1) Acrylic glass (I used green 4mm thick)
2) Thick art paper
3) Plywood (6mm thick)
4) Usual desktop lamp.
5) 8 small neodymium magnets
6) Double sided tape
7) Laser cutter
8) Hot glue
9) Grinder straight for acrylic glass The assembling process is easy to see on photos, here is a short description:
1) I took apart the desktop lamp and used the metal from it's cap as a stand for bulb in my lamp;
2) I lasercutted the inside skeleton cap, stand from acrylic glass and vertical frame from plywood;
3) I lasercutted and assembled the back side with a small window with magnets, that will be used for easily changing the bulb and a small cutout for the wire.
4) I grinded the backside so it will perfectly fit and attached the it and the bulb with stand using double sided tape and hot glue;
5) I attached outside skeleton stand, using transparent double sided tape;
6) I engraved on the art paper the patterns and the text with congrats (Sides 1, 2, 3) and attached them to the vertical skeleton using double sided tape; One of the sides (with donuts) I attached so that the engraved part is inside the lamp, so you can see the picture only when you switch on the lamp;
7) I attached the outside skeleton using hot glue.

title: K8200 / 3Drag zaxis probe servo mount - Improved and parametric

description.text:
A modified version of this servo mount:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:262892 It is stiffer than the original and can be placed closer to the extruder. You will need to print the servo extension from the original design. The parametric openSCAD source file is also included so you can position servos of different sizes were you want them.

Fits a 9g servo from tower pro or hyperion DS-09 Printed in 0.3mm layer PLA and a 2mm brimm using fairly fast settings.
Printed in ABS to prevent sagging due to heat. I needed to drill out the servo mounting holes. You might increase the drill diameter a little to avoid this. If you modify the design for different servo size then remember to add a little extra space on top of the real servo size.

printed on Replicator 2 with rafts and no supports.

Robbie is a classic robot from one of my favourite science fiction movies, "Forbidden Planet".
I've printed and painted 3 versions and tried to make the helmet as transparent as possible using translucent PLA.

This time, I've provide STL files that don't need any scaling or change of orientation when you print.
No supports are needed but rafts are highly recommended, especially for the helmet.
I printed these on a MakerBot Replicator 2 using PLA.
If you can, use translucent PLA for the helmet and mouth.
I used standard resolution for every part except the antennae which used high resolution.
After printing, paint and glue together!

remixed_from.title: OOML - C++ Object Oriented Mechanics Library

description.text:
With this new component of the C++ OOML library, you can generate 3D chars, as you make them in C++
Make your banners, label you things, do whatever you want and leave your personal signature

OOML stands for Object Oriented Mechanics Library. The OOML is a set of tools written in C++ that allow designers to create mechanical parts using the C++ language.
OOML applies the model of Object Oriented Programming to Mechanical Designs. Parts can be inherited from others. A part can join together other existing parts, and so forth.
OOML is Open Source, you can use it, modify it, share it.

Just go to the OOML wiki. Check how to install it, and learn how to use it. There are plenty of tutorials: http://iearobotics.com/oomlwiki/doku.php Example of use at http://iearobotics.com/oomlwiki/doku.php?id=primitives:char

author: cliftonj

description.text:
This is a redesign for an 8040 printable propeller with a 5.5mm (13/64") bore. This prop was designed to keep the minimum cross section above .8mm allowing it to be more easily printed, though at a small efficiency loss. The propeller will require support on one edge, which makes it very easy to remove. I can redesign this for some different center hole diameters if requested, just give me some time as I am pretty busy. Here is a short video with the prop on a motor: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v6yClT12Ges&feature=plcp
I will also be uploading a 5030 prop once it is flight tested. I printed mine on a Fablicator using Kisslicer.

I suggest using 2-3 shells, 100% fill, and a layer thickness no larger than .2mm (I used .17mm with excellent results.) I also used an extrusion width of .4mm
The propeller will need support material enabled. 
I highly encourage printing this from PLA, since the thermal contraction of ABS will often warp/crack the blades. 
Once printed, remove the support, ream the hole to 13/64", and sand the edges a bit to remove any leftover support or jagged edges. 
I've spun this up on a 1300KV hextronic 24g brushless outrunner with a 2S lipo and it puts out some pretty impressive thrust. The propeller feels every bit as strong and durable as a bought one (Though I have not crashed it yet) 
I've uploaded a few different orientations as well as CW/CCW Pairs for easy printing.

A spool handle to be used on top of 3D printer frame. Originally designed for Monkeyfab Prime3D, but the handle should also fit similar 6 or 7.5 mm thick frames. The axis and the 2 round plugs are designed for 103 mm wide spool with 53 mm internal diameter. Maximum external spool diameter is 30 cm. Handle can be also used for loose filament without a spool - see the last photo :) There is a thing variation for another type of spool - see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:302027 for details. For more photos please visit my blog (Polish)
http://3dwpraktyce.pl/2014/04/uchwyt-do-szpuli-z-filamentem-wersja-druga/

I used PLA with 0.2 mm layer for triangle supports and spool plugs. The axis is cut into 2 parts that should be glued together - I printed it with 0.1 mm layer what gave it a nice smooth surface. No supports in slicer are required for printing Thing parts. The yellow support consists of 2 triangle symmetric parts:
  • SpoolHandle-a.stl / SpoolHandle-b.stl (6 mm printer frame)

Until things have been cleared up re: licensing, selling and generally being cool with the OS community again. ** Brief: to create an open design that allows people with varying levels of arthritis to use aerosol cans. Existing products on the market are either very expensive or still require quite fine dexterity to use. We designed and built these using mainly a laser cutter and acrylic sheet stock, with some use of a lathe to turn a flexible plastic part. Created as part of the Hackshack project for Full Circle Arts, Manchester. http://www.fullcirclearts.co.uk/projects/hackshack-all-about-the-process/ Materials list: 5mm acrylic sheet 3mm acrylic sheet Delrin or Nylon plastic bar stock M5 + M3 hardware, see design files for full listing

Laser cut the vector files.
Turn the delrin or nylon part using lathe.
Assemble using hardware listed in design files.
'pop' on to aerosol can and use lever to actuate the cap / nozzle.

description.text: In line with my desire for a 3D printer like the CupCake that uses conductive build material, here is a printable resistor. This one has 0.05 mm traces (or scale it until it does) and many more turns than http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2967 does, so it should provide much higher resistance (calculation, anyone?). The script could generate other trace sizes and numbers of turns, and I will modify it to do capacitors as well as possibly release it at some point. Made in Python, Inkscape, and Blender. http://makezine.com/go/makerbot Update: Using an Archimedean spiral approximation, I think this would be about 1.33 ohms in copper, 86.9 ohms in nichrome, 17.4 ohms in lead, 1.65 megaohms in sea water. I imagine this could be raised quite significantly if one could print the resistor in layers along the Z axis (at the same resolution and trace size, 10 times per millimeter).
This is a 2D design extruded so it has volume. Print with conductive material. High resolution necessary.

comments.text: In electrophysiology and astronomy it is helpful to reliably produce resistors in the range 20 meg ohms to 100 gig ohms.  For example a TL084 fet input amp (input impedance 10^15 ohms, output impedance ~75 ohms), used as a voltage follower will easily track the millivolt voltages of nerve fibers or heart beat, but the wall resistance for a cell wall is often around 5 to 15 meg ohms,  5 meg can be used as a load resistor or to measure current flow.  (e.g. See Scientific American article ~1970 for tracking Daphnia heart beat in a jar of swamp water).  Whereas, a 500 meg resistor can bleed capacitative charge while reducing noise.  Similarly, a small CdS or indium telluride sensor can reliably sense the light from a single star but the impedance change, the resistance changes are 10^9 to 10^12 ohms.  A battery in series with a 10gig resistor and sensor can be used to create a voltage divider, An EEG 4 quad sensor using TL084 or equiv. can sense that voltage, and  the result can be used for scope alignment or for a star or satellite tracker.
comments.author: vinyard

comments.text: DuPont has inks that could be used to print resistors - years ago we did thick film circuits. Resistors were typically screen printed, fired and then trimmed with laser. The same applied to conducting strips. Soldering was achieved by screen printing solder paste on the contact points. Components was either electronically or manually (prototyping) placed - the beauty was the placement did not have to be absolutely accurate as the solder will help to pull it in position on the tabs as soon as that was heated.

title: 18500 Li-ion Battery adapter to replace 3 x AAA cartridge

description.text:
This is an adapter you can put an 18500 rechargeable battery into so that it's snug in the place of a 3 x AAA cartridge, like in a lot of LED flashlights. The lower battery voltage (3.7 for Li-ion vs. 4.5V for alkaline) is pretty much offset by the lower internal resistance of Lithium electrochemistry, so the flashlight appears just as bright.
Electrical safety is up to you; don't use this if you don't understand the risks.
That being said, I haven't had any issues with this in a Utilitech flashlight I got at Lowe's Home Improvement, similar to the one in the photo.
Edit: 3D print pictures up, check 'em out.
Note: It is designed for a 22mm inner-diameter cylinder; I found that it is a bit snug for precisely 22mm (difficult to remove, and you want to remove a rechargeable battery); I might redesign it for a little more flexibility.
I added a new version; it's 45mm tall; as always, you can adjust Z-height in Makerware to whatever you need. I also included a couple new pictures.

I printed in standard PLA (well, red colored) with no problems.  Having trouble printing anything in soft PLA on my Replicator 2.  I just gave it 2 shells and 15% fill at a .2mm layer height.  The walls are thin, so it's probably solid, as the walls are 1mm thick (.4mm nozzle, 2 shells each side).  The print, at 50mm, is a little longer than the battery, so you might want to print it at Z-height 90% or so, maybe even just 10% so you have a shorty at either end of the battery, whatever works for you.  It doesn't bang around in the flashlight as much now.

title: Flying Chariot for Space Zombie Gaming
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I've been convinced by some friends to pull one of my old miniatures armies out of retirement.  In the interest of avoiding intellectual property snafu's we'll call it a space zombie army.  The game has changed a lot since I last played and I now need to update my supply of models.  Ever since the company that makes the game got too DMCA happy on the fan who posted a tank here, they are blacklisted from companies I can purchase from; it's all custom models from here on out.  Anybody who would use this can no doubt recognize the game and army I'll be playing without me using any trademarked/copyrighted terms.
This is the first model in the series.  Eventually I'll be making a cannon to sit where the pilot is in this model to play this as a related model in game.  After that I'll be scaling this up to make the larger aircraft in the army.  Everything will be based on this model and I thought I would share it now in case any one better at CADing cannons wants to jump on board.  Here's to hoping...
Obligatory:  This model uses no non original artwork.  No part of the posted STL files is property of any one other then me.  This model is not actually intended to resemble the official models closely.  The design of this model is based on asking 3rd party judges at the local tournaments what it would take to have a proxy they would accept.  This model is not even intended to comply with the official game rules other then through the proxy rules at local 3rd party tournaments.  Please don't DMCA me.

description.text:
Elmwolf's mailbox numbers have some small problems in their stl files -- the parts are (almost) all offset by a thousand in their X and Y coordinates, and so slightly jagged from floating point imprecision.

There are two versions -- one with a completely flat top, one with a slight bevel to the top surface.

description.text: This is basically the lazy/cheap person's way to level a bed without a dial gauge. When built, you basically have a clunky gauge that works exactly the same, and slides along the x-axis of your printer while you adjust the bed.

Print.
Use an M8 tap to cut a thread in the hole through the side of the part.
Insert the callipers (you may need to temporarily remove a little clip that screws onto the bottom of them).
Insert an M8 bolt/bit of threaded rod into the hole you just tapped, and tighten against the callipers to hold them in place.
Put some elastic bands around the callipers and the nubs on the side of the printed part.
Level stuff :)

comments.text: This method may work for machines where the smooth x rods are equal distance away from the bed (side by side), but it won't work for machines where the rods are one on top of the other, such as the Printrbot.

title: (Discontinued project) Clay's direct drive extruder: 3-Piece, Latching, Easy Print (Printrbot Jr. V2)

description.text:
NOTE: I HAVE STOPPED WORKING ON THIS FOR A LITTLE WHILE Thank you printrbot for publishing the drawings for the Jr. v2! disclaimer: I haven't [fully] tested it yet
    • UPDATES:
    ->V1.1 (4-19)
    -changed radii of various things
    -trimmed a bit off the body to save material and time, also for better clearance inside
    -rounded that a corner on the latch
    -added teeth on bottom of the inside when the extruder is held... for anticipated heat problems
    -packed it into one STL file So I've been playing with printrbot Jr v2 extruder parts for a while now... I wanted to challenge myself to make this extruder with the following features:
    -really easy latching, unlatching
    -3 pieces to print (minimum mechanical parts)
    -doesn't require any metal parts not already within the PBJrV2's extruder
    -could be printed without supports
    -fits in my printrbot
    (not yet made) - modular support for fans in various places and so I made this. the latching mechanism works similar to the original but puts less strain on the frame and is easier to undo for filament changes.

screw sizes are likely to small, if you print this before i fix it be prepared to use a drill. I only followed the laser cut parts diagram  
note, the spring will be at the bottom of the screw and a washer (like one of the two found in the bearing) should be used between the spring and the latch

I love lithophane electric night lights, but sometimes a naturally-lit one is less intrusive; just place it near a window. Here's a simple stand for curved lithophanes having a radius of around 120-150 mm and a total thickness of 2.5mm. If printed in ABS, a range of radii will work thanks to ABS' flexibility. Use one each top and bottom, or just bottom if you prefer that look. The stand shown here was printed with PolyWood filament from Polymakr http://www.polymakr.com/ on an Afinia using the PLA profile, "Fine" speed, and 0.3mm layers. The lithophane of my parents' wedding photo was generated using PhotoToMesh http://www.ransen.com/PhotoToMesh/ and printed in Octave natural ABS on an Afinia at "Fast" speed and 0.20mm layers. The stand design can be edited on Tinkercad at https://tinkercad.com/things/kukqLSAmjSw. It uses the Shape Generator "Hi-Res Tube Segment" by Anthony Graglia.

Add some windows to your Replicator to help with cooling and drafts.

Print off hinges and clips (I use 6 hinges and 4 clips, 2 clips and hinges for front and 2 hinges and 1 clip for each side, see photos)
Cut out 3mm acrylic to shape. (It would be great if someone could attach a lasercut window thing to this)
Each clip and hinge needs a small cutout from the window for it to fit snugly.
Hinges are designed around 3mm steel bar (M3 bolts would also work).
Install and you are done.
I have included the .dwg file for anyone that wants to change it. edit: Drandolph has made a cut file for the windows; http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30894.

A card holder I made in Sketchup.
I made it specifically for the card game BANG! but regular sized playing cards should fit into it as well.

Please note the forward tabs aren't as strong as I would like. I applied some acetone after creation and that has strengthened them up.
I plan on making a modified version later but so far it has stood up to routine use without incident. I know there are lots of card holders out there but I liked having one side open to slide the cards out and I made mine with an angle so that the deck would stay put.

comments.text:

title: Printrbot Original Build Platform
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is my version of the build platform intended for the original Printrbot with the 6" x 6" build area. It's designed after beardface's 8" x 8" build area platform (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17717), but the hole spacing is designed to match Brook Drumm's original Printrbot (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16990).

Option 1: Get it cut out with a laser cutter/waterjet/giant mongo 36-axis CNC whatever-you-have. I got mine cut out through Ponoko, for all of $25 - you can find the part here http://www.ponoko.com/design-your-own/products/printrbot-original-build-platform-8576 Option 2: Print out the PDF with your old-fashioned ink-on-paper printer, and use it as a template! The platform is designed to measure 8.5" x 11" exactly, so a standard US Letter sheet of paper can be used as a hole location template. One word of caution - if you do this, I'd advise slightly oversizing the holes that attach the bed to the X axis rails. That way, even if your holes aren't in a perfectly perpendicular square, there'll still be enough compliance between the bed and the rails to avoid stressing the frame and linear motion components. Update 2-17-13: I fixed the holes for the heated build platform to match those on the 6" Printrbot HBP (available through the Printrbot store). Let me know if there are any other errors! Finally, if you want other versions of this file, please check out my website: http://blogs.sccs.swarthmore.edu/julianleland/printrbot-6-print-bed/

As standard, you get the openSCAD parametric CAd file so you can resize the box to anything you like.

Lightweight orbital shaker powered by a stepper motor for agitating cultured cells. Suitable to be placed in an incubator with variable-speed control panel on the outside.
View the animation in OpenSCAD if you want to see how it works.
Planar shapes are laser cut from acrylic - other parts are 3D printed. Stepper motor driven by EasyDriver board and Ardunio.

• ABS/PLA for 3D printing the following
    • 4x spindles
    • 4x joiners
    • 1x motor cog
    • 1x spindle cog
    • 12x rotational bearings
  • Acrylic to laser cut (or manually produce)
    • 2x lower plates
    • 1x shaking plate
    • Pillars to go between the two lower plates (3D printing is also possible here)
  • Optional extras
    • 'Dashboard' sticky pads to stick down culture flasks
    • Rubber feet to reduce vibrations

      Elect(ron)ic

  • 1x stepper motor with reasonable torque
  • EasyDriver board
  • Arduino (with keypad shield recommended)
  • Suitable DC power supply

    What's not yet included in the SCAD

  • How to attach motor to base-plate. This depends on exact motor dimensions. I just glued on acrylic offcuts to contain my motor as a temporary strategy. In due course I hope to produce a design where it's bolted on.
  • The pillars. You can use almost anything for these (e.g. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27736/#instructions )
    Video demo at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tr4ByE6NLZ4
    Some more info and at http://splasho.com/orbit.

title: Disco Dan the Dancing Man
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: With a flip of a switch, you can have "Disco Dan the Dancing Man" perform a Disco revival right on your own desktop! And who wouldn't? Designed to operate with 2 "AAA" batteries or a 3VDC power supply. Video of "Disco Dan the Dancing Man" prototype is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=41lB4yB8bLc. If nothing else, the wife wanted it, and for me, it was an interesting experiment in sliding dovetails as well as an extension of work regarding rack and pinion drives. Oh, and did I mention the wife wanted it? Printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" Settings.

Study "Assembly.skp".  
A sincere word of caution before you proceed.  Depending on your printer, slicer, printer settings, printer adjustments, colors chosen, etc., etc., etc., you may need to sand, trim, file, etc. the various moving parts for smooth and continuous operation, or you may not be able to print a part.  I've designed many things using Sketchup 8 and printed them in PLA using Makerware 2.3.3.42.  Each print is tested by running for days before published.  However, I occasionally get a comment that a part and/or entire thing cannot be printed or doesn't work.  I promise I print 3 copies of each thing, and if they all work, I publish it.  That being said, if you wish to continue the Disco revival, proceed on.   
Obtain the following parts:  
1) Gear Motor -  Polulu part number 2366.  
2) Battery Holder -  Radio Shack part number 270-0398.  
3) Switch -  Radio Shack part number 275-0624  
4) 2 "AAA" batteries.   
5) Coaxial power jack - Radio Shack part number 274-1583.  
6) 3VDC power supply - Radio Shack part number 273-315 or 273-316.  
7) White lithium grease.   
Print the "Disco Dan the Dancing Man" parts.  
After printing "Figure Stick.stl", carefully loosen the 4 joints and remove any stray filament if necessary using a modeling knife.  Note the hip joint has less movement than the remaining joints.  
After printing "Base.stl", carefully snap off the four hold down disks (these disks assist in minimizing warping) and trim, sand and/or file the surfaces smooth.  
Slide "Gear Rack.stl" into "Base.stl".  This should slide very freely.  If not, slide it back and forth repeatedly until it slides freely.  
Slide the gear motor into "Base.stl" until the shaft is even with the exposed surface of "Gear Rack.stl".  Install the switch and coaxial power jack into "Base.stl".  Solder a red wire between the gear motor "+" terminal to the "Center" terminal on the coaxial power jack.  Also solder the battery holder red wire to the "Center" terminal on the coaxial power jack.  Solder a black wire between the gear motor "-"  terminal to either contact on the switch.  Solder a black wire between the remaining switch contact to the coaxial power jack "Shell" terminal.  Solder the battery holder black wire to the coaxial power jack "Switch" terminal.  This wiring will allow either battery or power supply mode of operation, and in either mode, the switch will turn this thing on or off.  
Slide gear motor the remainder of the way into "Base.stl".  When positioned correctly, the motor shaft should extend 4mm above the exposed surface of "Gear Rack.stl".  
Press "Gear Motor.stl" onto the shaft of the gear motor, taking notice of the motor and gear flats.  
Slide the battery holder into "Base.stl".   Make sure the wires are positioned in the wire wells and not pinched between the surfaces of the battery holder and "Base.stl".   
Lubricate "Gear Motor.stl" and Gear Rack.stl" with white lithium grease.  
Turn the switch on a make sure "Gear Rack.stl" slides freely on "Base.stl" and the gear motor isn't stressing (if it is, you'll hear a gear whine sound, and all that needs to be done is to raise the gear slightly until the gear whine stops).  
Turn the switch off.  
Press "Cover Base.stl" into the under side of "Base.stl".  
Press "Cover Gear Rack.stl" onto "Gear Rack.stl".  
Slide the feet of "Figure Stick.stl" into the foot holders on "Gear Rack.stl".  Bend the legs of "Figure Stick.stl" outward if necessary to hold "Figure Stick.stl" in place in the foot holders.  
Turn it on and Disco!

EDIT: Uploaded dodecahedral enzyme from Geobacillus stearothermophilus, 1b5s This is a complex which forms the catalytic core of the pyruvate dehydrogenase multienzyme. The structure is made of 24 copies of a single protein; three copies make up each vertex of the cube. Pyruvate dehydrogenase is an enormous enzyme that connects the process of glycolysis, by which sugars are broken down, to the process of aerobic respiration. This enzyme is actually from the bacterium Azotobacter vineladii; the human version of the enzyme forms a dodecahedron. Read more about it here http://www.rcsb.org/pdb/101/motm.do?momID=153 1eaa in the pdb.

comments.text: That's amazing, man! I've been trying to convert some .pdb structures into printable .stl files myself. Did you use MeshLab?
comments.author: DechAmim

comments.text: No I used UCSF Chimera. Using Chimera you can import pdb files from the internet, then export them as .stl. Then I import the .stl files into rhino, and select which meshes I want to print. Sometimes Chimera makes tiny floating specks where long side-chains were and I don't want to try to print those. Also at this point I rotate the model into the printing orientation. I try to make the pointy part of it face down because that eliminates the surface area that looks ugly due to being printed on support. Then I export the stls I want to print and pass them through netfabb cloud to properly union them together. Finally, I import those fixed stls into KISSlicer and observe the toolpath for irregularities. Once all those test are passed I go on to print.

title: Auto Off! Automatic 3D printer Shutdown.  Complete power off.

description.text:
Short version: Printer finishes, and lowers the hotbed but stays on.
Now printer completely shuts off then the hotbed is lowered. =) Long version:
So I print a LOT.
I don't sacrifice my time by babysitting or staring at the printer. Plus it stinks.
I have a webcam to remote monitor the printer so I know if it had a problem such as not feeding filament or the part came off the hotbed, also so that I know if the print finished because the hotbed will be lowered outside of the webcam view. But then I have to go upstairs to turn the printer off so it isn't sitting there running the fan and power supply for no reason. So I made an "Auto Off!" box to hold a pressure switch, an override power ON switch, a green light for Armed, and a red light for stop.
Now when the webcam shows the hotbed was lowered and therefore the printer is done, it has also shut off the printer completely! (But the webcam stays on unless plugged into the same outlet.) I then got a 120V AC relay from Radio shack for $5, but the coil runs on 32V DC. Sure I can use a single Diode as a half cycle bridge rectifier and have 60V DC in a snap. But then I have to use Ohms Law bla bla bla for a resistor that would get hot and a bunch of math and run the power cord through it, plus draw 3v DC for the LEDs etc. I did find this GE Remote controlled power plug thing. Remote long lost. So I wired in a telephone jack to it and the Auto Off box, and Bang! Simple as that! The GE box is just a relay with it's own power supply for it's coil, outlet passthrough and some remote control chips I bypassed after plugging it in and poking around with some continuity probes from the multimeter. Best printer upgrade ever!
Aside from putting the power switch from the back to the FRONT as it should have been. I put the Auto Off Box up here so others can try.
Please don't steal my idea and sell it.
I however will sell this as a kit if I can find some more GE boxes.

2 LEDs (optional)
Pressure switch
Override DPDT slider switch. GE remote power box just because it has a relay.
Instructions for wiring would be a big chore, if you can't figure out that LEDs are just one way diodes, and switches are just... switches.. or how to use a relay then you couldn't handle this and should just buy a kit.
However with the pictures and the idea, many 3D printer people should be able to imitate this easy. Please share any improved versions of this!
I wish the firmware had a "shutdown when finished = true" option! If you would like me to build this for you, contact me via activezombie.com or [email protected] or youtube.com/wwwactivezomebie I will find the parts and we go from there.

comments.text: You sir have a faulty printer design and are the second person that fears their printer will somehow become even hotter when it is off than it is with the power on.   Your concern is misinformed.    I have over 240 hours print time with zero clogs.  Heat cannot clog your print head nozzle.  Furthermore if your printer is unclogged while powered on and running with full heat, it only becomes colder when powered off, not hotter.  In fact it gets colder when it finishes printing regardless of you turning it off or leaving it on.

comments.author: dxm13

comments.text: One issue -- when you hard-power-off the device, it shuts off the fans.  Usually the fans would keep running for a while to stop the print heads steppers from overheating.
comments.author: Corona688

comments.text: That is not a problem.  If your steppers are overheated with the fans running, it would already burn out and break.  Therefore the stepper motors are NOT overheated with the fans running.  Therefore if you hard-power-off the device and the fans shut off, your stepper motor has shut off also and will not increase in temperature.  So your stepper motors will not get hotter, but instead only get colder.  Therefore fans are not needed when you turn off your printer.    (Yes I realize I used the word "therefore" quite a lot, but I needed to express my point.)
comments.author: Corona688

comments.text:
The stepper motors need fans because they are bolted straight to the metal hotend. The fans keep the motors from getting as hot as the hotend.
The motors are STILL bolted to the blazing-hot hotend once you turn it off -- but now have no way to be cooled. The hotend will cool down, yes -- by leaking heat into the motors!
It will all cool down eventually, but the motors will get HOTTER before they get cooler.
comments.author: activezombie

comments.text:
Because I know you are inept I will explain with low grade math.
Lets pretend that the hot end gets up to 240F with fans on.
Lets pretend that ALL 240F gets leaked into the motors while the printer is on.
If the hot end is at 240F (or any number you wish to use) with the fan on, and your printer is printing, then that means your motors have NOT burned out.
That means your motors can survive any theoretical number you use for this basic math.
Now lets pretend you turn off your printer so that the fans shut off.
Think about what has happened.
At this moment the Hot end is at your theoretical temp of 240F (or other theoretical number) and not higher.
Your hot end is not magically getting hotter.
Your fans are no longer cooling anything, however nothing is getting hotter than 240F (or other theoretical number).
We already know the printer prints at 240F (Or other theoretical number) without burning out your motor, because your printer was printing and not catching fire.
Because nothing is getting hotter now that everything is off, including the fans,,
That theoretical 240F can "leak" into the motor if it wants to and you don't care.
The motor was already exposed to 240F from the hot end.
The hot end is cooling by the second, not getting hotter.
It is cooling because of the air, heatsinks, Obama Care, and me cause it is touching other metal parts including the motor.
The motor does not care because it was already under 240F (Or other theoretical number).
The motor is being exposed to less heat by the second. Not more.
The motor is not getting hotter because the hot end is not getting hotter.
The hot end is not getting hotter because the hot end is no longer being heated.
The fan was only keeping the heat in check while it was being heated.
Turning off the fan does not make any unpowered part hotter.
Get it?
comments.author: Corona688

comments.text:
I tried to be nice to you despite your lack of understanding. I realize this is hard for you to understand because the hot end is hot, and the fans are for cooling. So you believe without cooling, they will get hotter.
Yes the motors are attached to part of the hotend. The hot end has already leaked heat into the motors while the system is turned ON. The hot end will only DROP in temperature when powers off, not get hotter.
The Fans, even if we pretend that they are blowing on the motors when they are not, no longer cool the hot end when turned off. HOWEVER the hot end is now DROPPING in temp, not getting hotter after you turn it off.
Therefore the motor already gets "heat leaking into them" during printing, at a temperature that is already as hot as they will EVER get. Because the hot end is not getting hotter, the motors are also not getting hotter.
The Fans limit the max temp of the hot end.
We can pretend that the fans limit the max temp of the motors if you want to be incorrect, but still the end result remains the same. The motors are still connected to part of the hot end that is powered off and not getting any hotter than they were with the fans running. The heat from the hot end can "leak" into the motors all they want, but they will be EQUAL TO and NOT greater than the max temperature of the hot end while the hot end was running. BUT only for a moment because heat is instantly dropping on the hot end now that it is turned off, and not rising. So the motor temp is NOT getting hotter. You are a fucking idiot.
Furthermore! There is NO SUCH THING as a "hard-power-off" because the "off" switch is literally connected to the power cord and instantly kills ALL power to the machine. The transformer takes about 2 seconds to discharge the remaining power no matter what you do. Ripping the plug out of the wall is the same as using the off switch or my auto off. There is NO "soft-power-off".
Once again, your hot end is NOT magically getting hotter by some nuclear rule cell or omni overdrive cold fusion. It is getting colder. The motor is getting no more heat then it ever did while the fan was on. The fans do not cool the motor anyway. The heat form the hot end + power + fan is LESS THAN the heat from the hot end - power - fan because the hot end is DROPPING in temp not going up.
You have locked yourself into a statement that defines your intelligence as stupid.
Please go away.
comments.author: Corona688

comments.text:
That's a very longwinded way of saying you don't understand thermal conduction.
Warning duly given, I leave now.
comments.author: activezombie

comments.text:
That is a long way of saying you believe in fair tails, God, and magic self heating parts that get hotter when unplugged.
Forget about the fact that turning off your printer with the off switch does exactly the same thing as the auto off you are objecting to.
The heat sinks are not attached to the motor. Look again.
You have the heat sink, Then the hot end, then the extruder, then the motor.
I repeat, the heat sink is not attached to the motor.
The hot end has conducted all of the heat that it ever will conduct to the motors while the printer is on.
You admit the hot end is getting cooler.
Heat leaves the hot end into the heat sink, separated from the motor by over half an inch.
Heat conducts just the same as when it is on, or off, however much enters the motor is not increased by the lack of fans simple because the heat source is no longer getting hotter than it would have without those fans.
So you can literally pretend those fans are still running, keeping the heat of the hot ends down.
Heat sinks still work just slower, but there is no rush when it is no longer getting hotter.
Please do not use big words you do not understand.
comments.author: Corona688

comments.text:
Simple thought experiment: A chunk of metal 200C hot is bolted to
a chunk of metal 50C hot. A heating element has been keeping the hot part hot, and a fan has been keeping the cool part cool.
Turn off the heater and the fan at the same time. What will there temperatures be a minute later? 5 minutes? 10 minutes?
P.S: Of course the fan cools the motor. I can only assume you thought it was for heating the room?
comments.author: activezombie

comments.text:
PS: The fan doesn't cool the motor, it certainly IS there to cool the block holding the heater.
It is connected to that block, not the motor. Buy a printer and you will see.
comments.author: Corona688

comments.text:
Apples to Oranges.
The fan is NOT connected to the motor. It is connected to the heat sink.
The fan is connected to the heat sink, the heat sink is connected to an aluminum block.
The block is connected to a hot end and nozzle.
The block is also connected to the motor.
The fan is not connected to the motor and is not blowing air on the motor.
The air does not make contact with the motor.
I am speaking of a Flashforge Replicator 2x.
The Replicator 2x does not have a "soft power off".
The off switch cuts off the power cord from the wall and shuts off everything, including the fan.
If you believe that the motor itself sucks up more heat from the heat sink that is not connected to it when the printer is off, and you further believe this is a problem,
Then you are disagreeing with the design of the printer itself which is to turn off completely when you flip the off switch.
Because Replicators do not burn out under normal use, you should reconsider your twisted bullshit theory.
Again, the fan is not connected to the motor.
The air from the fan never blows over the motor.
The heat sink is not touching the motor.
Plastic extruder parts separate the motor from the heatsink and fan.
You said you would leave with your bullshit, and yet you remain.
comments.author: Corona688

title: any-angle rod clamp, for diagonal reprap support

description.text: This rod clamp allows you to connect two 8mm rods at any angle you want. The scad can easily be modified for other rod sizes. Intended for a diagonal reprap support.

Print 2, clamp around rods at desired angle and secure with an M3x25 screw (with nut and washers).  For a diagonal brace like the one in the picture you'll need an 8mm threaded rod around 25cm long. comments.text: Your game will not work as-is. There is no difference between the object and the holes they fit in consequently they will be too tight to slide in. It's generally a good idea to make your holes 0.2mm bigger all around than the object you're fitting for a tight fit, and 1mm wider all around for a loose fit. Consderng this is a child's game I might be so bold as saying 2mm wider in some cases, especially since tinkercad doesn't made a beveled edge an easy thing to do. I might also recommend making your placing block a table with legs (sticking up for printablity).
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: I fixed it and added legs thanks for your help
comments.author: cymon

comments.text:
Fun fact, you actually got the measurements exactly right, and that's the problem. Virtual fit is not real life fit.
Since you're working on this let me give you a little more feedback. If you're making this for home 3D printers you'll want to flatten the top of the table and flip it over to avoid overhang and bridging.
Now as to the game itself, the star peg doesn't fit in it's hole, but it does fit in the hexagonal prism hold and cylinder hole. The half cylinder is slanted for whatever reason. And the cylinder will almost fit in the hexagonal prism hole.
Hope you don't mind this sort of feedback. i realize this was probably just a silly little project for it's own sake but it can be beneficial to explore things like this. Who knows, you may make something someone needs.
fixed I think
comments.author: cymon

comments.text:
Better, and it will print this time, but not without supports on the overhanging legs. See how they're danging in mid air there? Why not just put them flat to the build surface, level with the top of the table (the top that is facing down, not the top that is... you know.) It's best, when possible, to design for support-less printing since supports are not always clean and reliable and require an additional cleanup step where as something that prints support-less will spring off the build plate ready to enjoy.
So the only other thing is to be sure that none of the pegs can fit into any of the other holes, which I'm pretty sure the small triangle and the heart could do.
I feel a little guilty because I, myself, have no intent to print this. You seem willing to learn, so I'll offer my unsolicited opinions.

description.text: These are to reduce the noise by replacing one of the wood mounting plates with a better sound absorbtion material.  These are designs for printing in soft PLA or as use for templates for other material.

Will make a more complete write up once some more heat testing is done due to being printed in soft PLA. 2 versions, one for the x any axis motors printed .2mm narrower than the original for a rubber grommit on the bolts, and a z axis and extruder motor. So far no problems. Basics are:
  • Print in soft PLA, or normal PLA to use as templates for other material.
  • Remove the 1 motor mount plate that is closest to the wall and add this plate as replacement.
  • Replace motor. I would check screws after a print to make sure they are still as tight as you want them and confirm belt tension has remained.
    • Note: In doing this I noticed that the stock POT setting from UM for the motors was much too high and the motors were burning. Tuned them back and now they are warm but you can keep your hand on them.

comments.text: i've only printed with it for a few days but so far the tension on the belts has stayed, maybe it takes longer.  I do know the wood on wood was stuck good.  I'll keep and eye on it.  I've also put together a mount for the feeder but still need to do some work, but that goes a long way to removing the normal hum and squeek on retraction.  the wood housing acts like a drum.

Measured and test fitted an Iphone.

There is one very common operation that has to be done in nearly all the designs: beveling edges. It can be done on the convex side, for avoiding sharp edges, or on the concave side, for reinforce the part (avoiding the 90 degrees connection between parts). With the bevel library I am developing doing these two operations is a piece of cake. I have given some examples in this post: http://www.iearobotics.com/blog/2012/09/13/enhancing-openscad-ii-bevel-library/ The bevel library is part of the obiscad tools I am developing: https://github.com/Obijuan/obiscad More information in this wiki (in Spanish): http://www.iearobotics.com/wiki/index.php?title=Obiscad Many thanks to Miguel Angel de Frutos (MAF, http://www.thingiverse.com/MAF ) for his technical advices

How to bevel an edge: 1) Define 2 connectors with the same attachment point in the edge. One vector should be poiting in the edge direction and the other is orthogonal, pointing to the exterior bisec. 2) Invoke the Bevel() module (passing the connectors as parameters, as shown in the examples) 3) Use the difference operator Three examples are provided (along with their STLs) The code of your part with beveled edges looks like: difference()
{
My_part();
bevel(a1, a2, cr = 8, l=10); //-- First beveled edge
bevel(b1, b2, ....); //-- Second beveled edge
...
} The procedure for attaching buttress to you parts is similar, but in this case one of the connector should point to the inside bisector.

author: DougCostlow

description.text: The design of the nut holder on the PrintrBot LC is very cheap and not very stable. Here I have designed a nut holder that can with a few drilled out holes can be installed on the top of the nut support instead of on the bottom. You may have to change the settings on your printer. I used a layer height of .2mm and it turned out good. If you decide to modify this bracket do not make the walls any thinner than the 3 mm that they are as this will make them weak. I know because i have done it already. 3mm seems to do well. I put these together using Solidworks 2014 but you can use the software to your liking to change the design to your liking. This mod has also helped with my calibration and rod wobble. If you have any questions be free to send me a message. i will answer them when i receive them.

Well first I sat there looking at my printrbot for some time watching the rod wobble as the z-axis made every move. It bugged me and i looked closer at where the nut was placed. Very bad design if you ask me. I got out the calipers and started to design. i was tired of my prints being out of calibration and one side of the print being higher than the other. Once i had the measurements i put the dimensions into solidworks 2014 and designed away. Took a few hours to get it right and printed it 5 times before everything was correct. The left side needed to be different from the right and all i had to do was take out some of the wall.

description.text:
We wanted to try how the upcoming Lumia 920 feels in hands. So we quickly created a 3D model from the phone, printed it out and added picture of start screen.
The phone feels awesome and we are waiting to get real one in hands!
If you are also waiting for new Lumia 920, print it out with our miniFactory 3D printer and try how it feels. Sadly, the electronics are not included in print :)

The print needs quite much space on Z axis, since the model height is 130.3mm. Other dimensions are much lower. The Lumia 920 is only 70.8mm wide and 10.7mm thick. We added a "lifted" display so it can be seen in real printed part. It has 3 buttons on the side and about 1mm deep cutout for camera and flash in back of the model. We printed it out with following settings:
Layer height: 0.1mm
Nozzle diameter: 0.35mm
Perimeters: 2
Solid infills: 4
Infill: 0% The print took 4h 2mins with speed settings quite slow and filament used was only about 5 meters (1.75mm). Enjoy the model and print it out! :)

author: Kainednable

title: RC plane wing tips, spars and wing angled joiner

description.text:
Parts initially designed for the Experimental Airlines AXON model, can be easily rescaled and used in other  models with flat bottom, high lift wings.
The plane in its current configuration has a 6" or 150mm base chord, with a wing span of 54" and an AUW of 950 to 1300g depending on the motor, battery and camera options.

All parts can be printed with 20% infill and 2 shells.
Using a slurry of acetone and ABS is required for around 1/3rd from each end if you want a square inner edge for the wing tips. 
Have loaded 2 versions of the wing joiner with 5 and 15 degree cant to make a poly wing, with a nominal section lenght of 400mm (16") joined to a centre section of around 700mm. The strut holes are common, so linking with carbon rod is simple. The centre spar is spaced 3mm from the base plate, to allow for a support piece of the same foam board used for the skin if desired.
All of these parts are designed for use with a 3mm or 5mm foam board skin.

author: Kainednable

description.text: To allow the loft hatch panel position to be adjusted against the lift springs/bracket

I had a new loft hatch fitted to expand my storage options...but the mass produced hatch+ladder+frame design is defficient :
THe springs that assist pushing the hatch up also cause the hatch panel to slide in its mounting brackets resulting in damage to the wooden trim and ceiling as the hatch opens.
So I designed this part to adjust and prevent the slide.
Print one as shown, and one mirror image.
  • Offer up the jig part to the hinge plate and drill the 2 mount holes 2. 2.8mm diameter. (Setup 40mm from the drill tip to chuck, the pillars prevent drilling too deep.)
  • Screw the adjusters in place.
  • slacken the 6 panel>hinge bracket screws a touch.
  • Advance the SHCS to adjust.
  • Tighten the 6 screws.
  • repair, sand and repaint damage to woodwork.
    • Also needed :
    2 off M8 nyloc nuts - pop into the slot in the bottom.
    2 off M8x 25 SHCS (socket head cap screw)
    4 off No.8 x 1 1/4" woodscrews.

remixed_from.author: MoonCactus
remixed_from.title: Drop in replacement for the ultimaker extruder big wheel/gear

description.text:
Drop in replacement for Mk2 / Mk3 ultimaker 3mm filament feeder.
Wheel2 is my first version.
Wheel3 has larger holes and a support cylinder in the center.

I printed at 0.2mm using my Ultimaker and Cura.
Used gold PLA at 210degreesC Derived the gear+holes from MoonCactus and added the 3mm thick hex boss to replace the washer used in the wooden version. The boss clamps between the hex nut and 'acorn' nut so the gear dosn't wobble like the wood one. (I am using the Mk 3 knurled drive : https://shop.ultimaker.com/en/parts-and-upgrades/knurled-bolt-kit-version-3.html ) I printed 'wheel2' without support and the centre 8mm hole took a few layers to form properly and needed tidying with a knife - try with cura's support option, or print 'wheel3' and snap out the support cylinder after print. This gear runs better than the wood one - possibly because it is slightly smaller diameter accross the teeth tips - the teeth root diameter is the same as the wooden ultimaker laser cut unit. I havn't checked the STL/Scad data, but it could just be due to the rounding of the tips by the filament process. The small laser cut plastic gear has small root radi as a result of the laser process, whereas the wood large gear has sharp tooth tips. They seem to have been designed witout any root clearance, which is not advised for this reason (and others)!

comments.text:
Not quite the thing for me…
It's a little too thick, so it doesen't actually fit well. You have to use washers anyways, since It will touch the bolts otherways. Or did I get this wrong with the washers?
The other thing is, that the holes don't fit for adjusting the stepper motor, which is actually a quite important thing.
comments.author: maecka

comments.text: It's nice to be able to screw the feeder wheel tight. But my gear is still tilted quite a bit, at an angle to the rod. I wonder why. Maybe the uneven material that dropped from Cura's not-very-successful bridging attempt is tilting it? Or is one of the screw/nut/acorn tilted by design? Does anyone else have this problem?
